options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The mandatory synchronous virtual lecture was also recorded, so students could watch the recordings asynchronously after class if they wished.
The class had virtual lecture style courses that included small breakout discussions
na
If you were unable to attend the live virtual lecture, you could watch the recording.
lecture/seminar
Classes were recorded and available to watch on canvas
Recorded lectures and posted lecture slides as well.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a very detailed knowledge of New Kingdom Egypt and ancient Middle Eastern international affairs, as well as writing skills and historical contextualization.

I learned about the history of New Kingdom Egypt (going through each pharaoh) and how Egypt built and administrated its empire. At the end of the course, I also learned about the factors that led Egypt to lose its empire at the end of the New Kingdom period.
I developed a lot of knowledge on Egypt's New Kingdom as well as knowledge of archeological techniques and structures.
Knowledge of Egyptian New Kingdom. Ability to historically analyze different sources.

I gained knowledge about ancient Egyptian pharaohs, politics, and historical events during the New Kingdom Period. I developed skills relevant to reading and analyzing primary texts and sculpted reliefs. I also developed analytical skills useful for making inferences about periods of history with limited resources.

Knowledge of the Egyptian New Kingdom Empire, including history of the pharaohs, Egypt as an empire, and an introduction to archeological methods and findings. By examining archeological evidence chronologically and in different areas of Egypt, we learned about important historical moments, as well as the daily lives of ancient Egyptians.
I learned how to interact during a seminar course and how to manage college readings.
I feel like I became a better writer as a result, or at least more aware of citing sources and going more in depth. I also learned a lot about Egypt during the New Kingdom.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths of this course include the fantastic teaching, the generally engaging readings, the extra resources/podcasts, and the in class lectures. The only weaknesses would be the generally unhelpful breakout rooms and occasional irrelevant/drab readings (very rare).

Strengths: The professor had the right mix of presentation time and asking questions in my opinion. She often asked questions to the students while going through the presentation slides, but the questions were relatively easy to answer, so I never felt like I had constantly rack my brain in the class or that I was tiring myself out from thinking too much (which I often feel like I do in English classes, which are more discussion-intensive). The professor is very knowledgeable and often added a bit onto the students' responses too, so we learned a lot in class and my experience attending lectures is very positive. There also isn't that much work in the class and we had a tiny break in the middle of class to stretch our legs or go to the bathroom so that was nice too! Overall, the professor is very excited to teach the class, and I could feel that energy so that made my class experience very enjoyable :). This was my favorite class first semester.

Weaknesses: we didn't have a lot of timed assessments, so when the final rolled around, I felt a bit unprepared for how an exam in this class would feel like. However, the professor provided us with a study guide and tips for how to study for the final, so everything went fine :).

strengths: interesting material, engaging discussions/lectures, instructor is very knowledgeable and accommodating to students' needs
weaknesses: readings were sometimes hard to read and fully comprehend but gets better throughout the semester, review of material covered throughout the semester was limited
improvements: more opportunities (ungraded quizzes and refreshers during class) to review material covered throughout the semester would make studying for the final easier

Strengths include Prof. Moeller's lectures and enthusiasm for the subject, and the subject content itself. If you are interested in ancient Egyptian history and/or archeological investigations, this class will be super interesting! The online format was definitely a drawback for discussions, but overall these were also well facilitated and interesting. Course grading and assignment expectations were very clear throughout.

Professor Moeller was lovely. She was always very accommodating and her lectures were engaging. I liked the discussions we had during class, especially when we were asked to look at things from the perspective of an archaeologist. The class was sometimes a little disorganized, as we were prone to get a little behind schedule in lectures.

I really liked the break in class, it was nice to be able to stand up and stretch in the middle of class without seeming rude. It would've been nice to go to a museum in person, but that would be  unreasonable for this year.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual learning environment in this course was generally very good. My only complaint is with the breakout rooms, as they seemed generally unnecessary in such a small class.

Having a 2 to 3 minute break in the middle of class was very helpful for me to stretch my legs/go to the bathroom/not burn out from Zoom fatigue. We missed out on some of the more fun things this year like going to the MET in NYC to see the Egyptian art gallery because of COVID, but I think in a normal year that would've been pretty cool.
virtual discussions and office hours were successful and need not be improved
The annotated lectures worked well, and I think whole class discussions were the most negatively impacted by the online format. Breakout rooms were very useful.

I thought that the virtual seminar format worked surprisingly well. There were occasional technical issues, but there were only a few instances of people talking over others, which is something I was concerned about. Professor Moeller kept us engaged and interacting with a mix of breakout rooms, lectures, and general discussions. I appreciated this variety. She also provided all texts, which I found useful. We maybe could have employed a few more online resources (for instance we once did a mini quiz on Canvas, and I would have liked to have done another).

I really liked the break in class, along with the dialog being apparent on canvas. I don't know if that was a feature you added or canvas did, but being able to quickly find a comment about something discussed in class was really nice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would absolutely recommend this class to other students. Professor Moeller is wonderful, and her teaching is second to none; she's quite literally the expert in the field, as she does research directly in Egypt! The class is engaging and perfect for anyone with interest in Ancient Egypt, and you don't have to be an expert or great writer to do well. If you want a first year seminar with great content, a great teacher, and a moderate workload, this class is for you.

Yes! This is an amazing first-year seminar and the professor is very excited to teach the class and is super nice :). This was my favorite class my first semester at Yale because the lectures were engaging and the workload is fairly light; the professor 100% made an effort to include students in the discussion when talking about ancient Egypt.
Absolutely! This course was interesting, engaging, and the workload was never stressful. It's a great introductory course for anyone that likes history or Egyptology.
Yes. It's a very good first-year seminar, for students interested in ancient civilizations.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students; it was my favorite from the semester. The material is interesting and well organized so it's great for students who have little to no prior knowledge of ancient Egypt. The reading load was not overwhelming (30-40 pages a class) but was sometimes hard to get through because the material was unfamiliar (which gets better as the semester continues and you become more familiar with the course content). Plenty of time was given to complete the writing assignments. Small amounts of class time were dedicated to lectures, but the majority of class was spent discussing the main topic of the class (relevant primary texts and visual analysis of reliefs). Prof. Moeller is knowledgeable, engages with her students, and values student input during discussions and about the courses as a whole.

Yes, if they are interested in ancient Egyptian history, archeology, or just want to learn something new. The readings are very interesting, and if you do them you will have no trouble participating. The assignments and grading are very fair, with lots of feedback and clear expectations.
Yes! If this a topic you are interested in, I would definitely recommend it. I enjoyed the course a lot.

This was a really fun class. The work load was light (several 2 page papers and a few projects, check the syllabus) and relevant. It would've been nice to have the class in person, but professor Moeller made the class work despite that.
